titleStmt.title: Description of University of Pennsylvania Ms. Codex 33: Libellus de speculativa mistice theologie

availability.licence: These images and the content of Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts Ms. Codex 33: Libellus de speculativa mistice theologie are free of known copyright restrictions and in the public domain. notesStmt.note: This manuscript is of particular interest because it appears to date from Gerson's lifetime and because the text of the Gerson works differs somewhat from that of the printed versions edited in the 1960's.
A detailed historical and textual discussion of this manuscript, written in May 1991 by Prof. Marvin Colker, Dept. of Classics at the University of Virginia, is on file in the Library.

msIdentifier.repository: Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts

msContents.summary: Contains the text of Gerson's De mystica theologia speculativa (pp. 1-68), De mystica theologia practica (pp. 69-111), and De passionibus animae (pp. 113-156). There is a short bibliographical appendix, Annotacio doctorum aliquorum qui de contemplacione loquti sunt (pp. 111-112). Also contains Pierre D'Ailly's De districtione in nocturnis pollutionibus, in an abridged form (pp. 162-163).

msItem.title: De practica contemplationis vel theologie mistice, p. 69
Annotacio doctorum aliquorum qui de contemplacione loquti sunt, p. 111
De distrecione [sic] in nocturis pollutionibus, p. 162

supportDesc.extent: 82 leaves : 151 x 109 (105 x 72) mm. bound to 153 x 112 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Parchment, ii + 164 + ii; 1-115 (even numbers supplied), [116-164]; 16th-century arabic pagination in ink, modern pagination in pencil, upper outer corners. Contemporary roman numerals appear on f. 35 and f. 62.

collation.p: i, I⁴, II-III⁵, IV³, V⁵, VI⁵(+2), VII⁵, VIII-IX⁴, i.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Written in a gothic bookhand. The D'Ailly text is written by a different scribe than the Gerson texts.

decoDesc.decoNote: Headings and initials in red. Some initial spaces blank.

origin.p: Written in France in the first half of the 15th century, perhaps ca. 1420.

history.provenance: Formerly owned by the Carthusian monastery at Castres, France (see inscription, f. 1); Henry Holmes; Ralph Emerson; Joseph Emerson; and Beloit College.
